Angie Bowen is creating things.

Angie Bowen https://angiebowen.com/

I write about the creative application of generative learning. My academic work sits at the intersection of psychology, education, & communication.

In addition to generative learning [1], I also write about whatever interests me in the moment. It's our unique combinations of interests and skills that allow for the cross-domain connections that make a mind garden [2] generative.

I'm a painter so visual art often makes its way into my work. I love designing websites and exploring the intersection of art and technology. That's what initially drew me to digital gardens [3]. I'm a huge fan of the indieweb and love to see individuals express themselves through personal sites.

I've been cultivating my personal mind garden in Obsidian for a couple of years and making some of these notes public is the next natural progression. It's easy to let individual notes sit in disarray when they're completely private. But when you begin sharing them with others, you have to organize and express them in a way that makes sense to someone else.

“Imagination is the Combining Faculty. It brings together things, facts, ideas, conceptions, in new, original, endless, ever varying, Combinations. It seizes points in common, between subjects having no very apparent connexion, & hence seldom or never brought into juxtaposition.”

~ Ada Lovelace

Footnotes

  1. generative learning: A theory of learning that says we learn best when we actively engage with new information through connecting it with existing knowledge. ↑
  2. mind garden: A creative personal knowledge management (PKM) system designed for generating and growing new ideas over time. ↑
  3. digital gardens: The portion of a person's mind garden they choose to make public. ↑
